Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC for Broadband Wireless Access and Applications Center Site at the Catholic University of America

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support creating a new I/UCRC Site of Broadband Wireless Access and Applications Center (BWAC) at the Catholic University of America (CUA). The CUA Site will complement existing BWAC Center strengths to develop novel technologies in the wireless domain. The new site, in combination with the existing center, addresses a critical area of American economy, and has potential to increase the societal ability to access broadband wireless services and to support development of broadband wireless as a platform for innovation. The I/UCRC Site will help recruit diverse and promising students into the electrical engineering and computer science programs at CUA. Research related to wireless realm will be seamlessly integrated with education. By involving undergraduate and graduate students directly in the projects of actual interest to industry, the center will better prepare the students in their career development, and enhance the intellectual capacity of the engineering and science workforce.

The CUA Site will address the technical challenges of broadband wireless access and applications with an integrative approach, and conduct research in the areas of software defined wireless networks, mobile edge cloud, cognitive radio networks, dynamic spectrum sharing, millimeter wave antennas and networking systems, Internet of Things, and wireless and mobile applications. The cooperative research efforts at the CUA Site will potentially make impactful contributions to advance wireless technologies and applications, software and hardware components, and wireless standards.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The IUCRC Site of Broadband Wireless Access and Applications Center (BWAC) at the Catholic University of America (CUA) addressed technical challenges and developed practical solutions for next-generation (5G & beyond) wireless networking systems. By collaborating with industry partners and other BWAC sites, the CUA Site conducted advanced research on millimeter-wave communications and networking, massive multiple-input and multiple-output (MIMO) beamforming, shared-spectrum access, wireless mobile applications, and mobile edge computing techniques. The outcomes of this project have advanced wireless technologies and applications, just as a few of examples, a reinforcement learning-based algorithm has been developed to optimize massive MIMO beam power allocation under time-varying traffic and network conditions; a new beam sweeping and beam search scheme has been developed to reduce the delay of initial access to millimeter-wave cellular networks; an adaptive video delivery system with mobile edge computing has been designed, which significantly improves the quality of experience of multiple video streams. Broadly, the BWAC CUA site, in combination with the center, addresses a critical area of American economy, and creates new technologies to satisfy the societal needs for next-generation wireless mobile communications and to support development of broadband wireless as a platform for innovation. The BWAC CUA Site has seamlessly integrated the research related to wireless realm with education. By involving graduate and undergraduate students directly in the research projects of actual interest to industry, the students are better prepared in their career development, which enhances the intellectual capacity of the engineering and science workforce.
